title: 112_hr718
content: The Act may be cited as the "Huntington's Disease Parity Act of 2011". Congress finds that Huntington's Disease is a progressive neurological condition causing physical and mental deterioration. Approximately 30,000 individuals in the US are affected, with 200,000 at risk. Symptoms include loss of movement control, cognitive decline, and behavioral changes. Adult-onset typically occurs between ages 30-50. Huntington's Disease symptoms include personality changes, irritability, mood swings, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive behavior, inability to concentrate, decreased motivation, and severe depression. The disease has different onset types: Adult-onset (30-50 years), Late-onset (after 50 years, milder course), and Juvenile (before 19 years, rapid progression). Due to the debilitating nature of the disease, individuals with Huntington's Disease are often unable to work and rely on Social Security Disability Insurance. Despite medical advancements, the Social Security Administration rules for Huntington's Disease have not been comprehensively updated. Despite medical advancements, the Social Security Administration has not updated its rules for evaluating neurological disabilities like Huntington's Disease since 1985. The term "Huntington's Chorea" used by the administration is outdated and inaccurate, failing to recognize the full impact of the disease. Individuals with Huntington's Disease often rely on Social Security Disability Insurance and face a 24-month waiting period for Medicare benefits. Individuals with Huntington's Disease face a 24-month waiting period for Medicare benefits after qualifying for Social Security Disability Insurance. The outdated guidelines for evaluating disabilities like Huntington's Disease need urgent revision due to the significant incapacitation faced by these individuals. Insurance guidelines for Huntington's Disease need urgent revision to address the significant incapacitation faced by individuals with this disease. There is a need to remove the 24-month waiting period for Medicare coverage, similar to the exemption for individuals with ALS. Revision of medical and evaluation criteria for disability caused by adult-onset and juvenile Huntington's Disease is necessary. The Commissioner of Social Security will update medical and evaluation criteria for Huntington's Disease for disability determinations under titles II and XVI of the Social Security Act. This includes amending sections related to neurological and mental impairments in adults and children. The Commissioner of Social Security will update medical and evaluation criteria for Huntington's Disease in disability determinations under titles II and XVI of the Social Security Act. This involves amending sections related to neurological and mental impairments in adults and children, including providing criteria for Juvenile Huntington's Disease. The Social Security Act is amended to waive the 24-month waiting period for Medicare coverage for individuals diagnosed with Huntington's Disease. This change applies to benefits under title XVIII of the Social Security Act for items and services provided after the enactment of this Act.
